sentence:
No Deus ex Machina for Lowes

Recent data suggest that the U.S. economy continues to improve, albeit quite slowly, and with quite a long way left to go before resembling anything like prosperity.
The good news is that sustained slow growth should allow for a sustained bull market, provided that investors keep their heads and keep investing only where there is value.

The market should therefore be more selective going forward, and it almost certainly will be, for neither the economy nor the bullish sentiment is strong enough to save investors who put money into losers.
One company that has been doing well in this environment is Lowes ( LOW ), the home improvement retailer.

Home improvement stores such as Lowes and Home Depot ( HD ) are often viewed as defensive stocks, or even as countercyclicals, since a poor economy prevents families from moving into new houses, which encourages people to spend what they can on home maintenance, renovation, and expansion.
That view is not supported by the fortunes of these companies over the last decade.

Lowes, in particular, lost 53% of its value in the 2008 crash, which is not as much as some, but was certainly painful for investors, especially considering that the stock did not regain its lost value until late in 2012.
And so, Lowes finds itself in the odd position that its revenue could decline as a result of either a very good economy or a very bad one.
For the last twelve months, the economy has remained in the goldilocks zone, but investors would be foolish to think that can last much longer.
In 2013, consumer confidence warmed sufficiently for homeowners to do the work they had been putting off during the recession, and Lowes spent the year benefiting from the pent up demand.
The stock has risen accordingly, but perhaps too enthusiastically based on the company's current P/E ratio of 26.

In one frequently hypothesized scenario, the improving economy could cause the Fed to finally enact its long delayed tapering of quantitative easing, leading to higher interest rates, a drop off in home buying, and a subsequent increase in home renovations which would increase Lowes's revenue and justify its high price.
There are multiple problems with this scenario.

The economy is hardly getting so hot as to fuel a wave of new home buying or to spook the Fed, and the slight upticks in the numbers have done nothing to moderate the extremely dovish remarks being made by Fed Chair Janet Yellen.
Even if the Fed does begin the taper sooner rather than later, high interest rates are likely to push as many people out of the goldilocks home improvement zone as they push into it.
High levels of spending on home renovation are typical when the economy is at this specific point on the recovery curve, but such booms don't last.
Lowes will be hard pressed to maintain its current level of revenue growth in 2014, and may not even be able to maintain its current revenue.
Furthermore, the notion that the Fed will swoop in and push more people toward home renovation is full of holes.
That leaves only a stock that has risen too high on too much optimism, and one which is unlikely to rise significantly higher in the near term.
I seek to capitalize on this weakness with a bear-call credit spread.
Look at the April '14 55/60 bear-call spread for at least a $1.10 credit.
Use limit orders.
This trade has a target return of 28.2% over 152 days, which is an annualized return of 67.7%, (for comparison purposes only).
The stock has to rise 6.3% to cause a problem.
Be aware that this is an aggressive trade, best undertaken by investors with diverse portfolios and high tolerance for risk.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
